title: 111_s3002
content: The "Dietary Supplement Safety Act of 2010" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act are included in this legislation. The Dietary Supplement Safety Act of 2010 introduces definitions for dietary supplement facilities and requires registration of such facilities with the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include dietary supplement facilities in the registration requirements. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act is amended to include dietary supplement facilities in the registration requirements. Registrants must provide the Secretary with facility information, trade names, and a list of dietary supplements manufactured. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act now includes dietary supplement facilities in registration requirements. Registrants must provide facility information, trade names, and a list of dietary supplements manufactured. Dietary supplement registrants must update their registration annually and include information on new or reformulated supplements before marketing in the US. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act now requires dietary supplement registrants to update their registration annually and provide information on new or reformulated supplements before marketing in the US. Amendments to the Act include provisions regarding new dietary ingredients in supplements, ensuring safety and compliance with regulations. Amendments to the Act include provisions regarding new dietary ingredients in supplements, ensuring safety and compliance with regulations. Manufacturers or distributors must provide the Secretary with information to demonstrate the safety of dietary supplements containing new dietary ingredients, which will be made public after 90 days unless it contains trade secrets or confidential commercial information. The Dietary Supplement Act requires registrants to update their registration annually and provide safety information on new ingredients. Submitters must maintain a substantiation file for safety claims, and facilities must show compliance before distributing supplements. The Dietary Supplement Act mandates that facilities or retailers distributing, labeling, or licensing supplements must obtain written evidence of registration and compliance. Non-compliance may result in civil monetary penalties under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The Dietary Supplement Act enforces penalties for non-compliance, including fines up to twice the profits from supplement activities. Amendments to the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act require reporting of adverse events related to dietary supplements. The Dietary Supplement Act mandates reporting of non-serious adverse events associated with dietary supplements marketed in the United States. Reports must be submitted to the Secretary in a specified format along with a copy of the supplement label. The Dietary Supplement Act requires the responsible person to annually submit a compilation report of non-serious adverse events to the Secretary. Records related to each report must be maintained for 3 years. The amendment also specifies the type of adverse event report to be submitted. "SEC. 418. RECALL AUTHORITY FOR DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS." The Secretary has the authority to issue a cease distribution and notification order for dietary supplements if there is a risk of serious health consequences, death, or if the product is adulterated or misbranded. This order requires immediate cessation of distribution and notification to distributors, importers, retailers, and consumers. This order instructs distributors, importers, retailers, and consumers to stop distributing, importing, selling, and using the supplement. An informal hearing must be provided within 10 days to discuss the actions required by the order. An informal hearing must be provided within 10 days to discuss the actions required by the order. If inadequate grounds exist to support the order, the Secretary shall vacate it. If a recall is deemed necessary after the hearing, the Secretary will amend the order to require a recall. An informal hearing must be provided within 10 days to discuss the actions required by the order. If inadequate grounds exist to support the order, the Secretary shall vacate it. The Secretary shall specify a timetable for the dietary supplement recall and require periodic reports on the progress. The Secretary has the authority to initiate the recall regardless of the person's decision to challenge the order. An amended order shall not include recall of the supplement from individuals and shall provide notice. The Secretary shall provide notice to individuals, at the expense of retailers, subject to risks associated with dietary supplements. If a significant number of individuals cannot be identified, notification shall be done pursuant to section 705(b).
